intro: Allium triquetrum var. typicum, commonly known as the three-angled leek, is a perennial bulbous plant native to Europe and western Asia. It features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of small, white or pale purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–40 cm and prefers well-drained soil in full sun. Its bulbs are edible and have a mild garlic flavor, often used in culinary applications. It is also valued in gardens for its ornamental appeal and ability to attract beneficial insects.
